Subject: New Paper on Novelty Search and Adaptive Neural Networks
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=va__u8OSs7mjUFFggbU4DbhPac-mJX9m9fyFRtZ_TEkJLsV3r5eb

Our new paper, which will appear at GECCO this summer, explores the idea th=
at novelty search is a potentially effective tool for evolving neural netwo=
rks that adapt during their lifetime (i.e. neural networks with plastic syn=
apses):

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2009/risi.gecco09.html

direc=
t link:
http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_gecco09.pdf

This idea is motiv=
ated by the intuition that it's difficult to evolve adaptive neural network=
s because evolution often finds strategies that improve performance at firs=
t without having to adapt.  In other words, evolving for adaptive behavior =
and synaptic plasticity is inherently deceptive.  Because novelty search is=
 hypothesized to effectively avoid deception, the potential is there for a =
powerful combination.  The results indeed show that novelty search is immun=
e to deception in the target domain (with respect to desired performance). =
 

More generally, this paper increases the body of evidence supporting the=
 counter-intuitive hypothesis behind novelty search that it is often more e=
ffective to ignore improvement in objective fitness than to select for it. =
 

We are hoping that this work inspires more research in evolving adaptive=
 (i.e. plastic) neural networks by offering a new tool to make it work more=
 effectively without worrying about non-adaptive (i.e. static) behavior dec=
eiving the fitness function.

ken
